review.title: Bringing Salary Transparency to the World: Computing Robust Compensation Insights via LinkedIn Salary
review.abstract: The recently launched LinkedIn Salary product has been designed to realize the vision of helping the world's professionals optimize their earning potential through salary transparency. We describe the overall design and architecture of the salary modeling system underlying this product. We focus on the unique data mining challenges in designing and implementing the system, and describe the modeling components such as outlier detection and Bayesian hierarchical smoothing that help to compute and present robust compensation insights to users. We report on extensive evaluation with nearly one year of anonymized compensation data collected from over one million LinkedIn users, thereby demonstrating the efficacy of the statistical models. We also highlight the lessons learned through the deployment of our system at LinkedIn.

sections.heading: 3. LINKEDIN SALARY MODELING SYSTEM DESIGN AND ARCHITECTURE
sections.text: We describe the overall design and architecture of the salary model system used in the recently launched LinkedIn Salary Product. Our system consists of an online component that uses a service-oriented architecture to retrieve remuneration knowledge that corresponds to the user's request, and an offline component to process anonymized remuneration data and generate remuneration insight. sections.heading: 5. EXPERIMENTS
sections.text: Next, we will present an evaluation of our LinkedIn Salary Compensation Insight calculation system, focusing on statistical models, examining the impact of outlier detection methods, evaluating the effectiveness of the regression model and Bayesian statistical smoothing, and evaluating the performance of statistical smoothing techniques across segments and under different parameter settings.

sections.heading: 5.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: As previously described, we have implemented our statistical models as part of the offline compensation calculation system and used them in production as part of the LinkedIn salary product. Our offline compensation calculation system is in a distributed computing environment with Hadoop. We conducted our experiments over nearly a year of anonymized compensation data collected from more than one million LinkedIn users in three countries (the U.S., Canada, and the United Kingdom). Due to privacy requirements, we only have access to data at the cohort level that includes anonymized compensation submissions (e.g. salaries for software engineers in the San Francisco Bay Area), limited to cohorts with at least a minimum number of entries. Each cohort consists of a set of anonymized compensation data that correspond to the individual, and each individual entry consists of values for different types of compensation. sections.heading: 6. LESSONS LEARNED IN PRACTICE
sections.text: Next, we present the challenges we have encountered and the lessons we have learned from the production deployment of our two pay models for offline workflow and REST service as part of the general LinkedIn salary system for more than a year, first during salary collection and later as part of the publicly launched product. We have conducted several iterative deployments of the offline workflow and REST service, always maintaining a sandbox version (for testing) and a production version of our system; the service has been distributed to multiple servers in different data centers to ensure better error tolerance and latency; one of the biggest challenges has been the lack of good public "ground truths" data sets. In the United States, the Internal Revenue Service has fairly complete salary data, but it is not public. Bureau of Labor Statistics provides aggregated data, but that brings the challenge of bridging LinkedIn taxonomy. Some states, for example, California, provide government salaries, but government jobs differ.

sections.heading: 7. RELATED WORK
sections.text: Salary information products: There are several commercial services that offer compensation information. For example, Glassdoor [6] offers a comparable service, while PayScale [8] collects individual salary submissions, provides free reports for detailed matches, and sells compensation information to corporations. However, the US Bureau of Labor Statistics [7] soon publishes a variety of pay and benefit statistics. Privacy: Maintaining users "privacy is critical in collecting compensation data. Initially, we wanted to use strict privacy practices such as differentiated privacy [14, 15]. However, we soon realized that these are not applicable in our context for the following reasons: (1) the amount of noise added to the quantities, histograms, and other insights (thereby depriving remuneration insights of their reliability and usefulness), as the worst-case sensitivity of these features to each user's remuneration data is applicable.

sections.heading: 8. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We explored the problem of calculating robust, reliable compensation insights based on anonymized compensation data collected from LinkedIn users. We introduced the design and architecture of the modeling system underlying LinkedIn's salary product, which was recently launched to increase transparency and help professionals make more informed career decisions. We highlighted unique challenges, such as modeling anonymized data, the lack of good evaluation data or policies and the simultaneous need for user privacy, data quality and product coverage, and described how we address them through mechanisms such as outlier detection and Bayesian hierarchical smoothing. We demonstrated the effectiveness of our models by conducting extensive experiments with anonymized data from over a million users. We also discussed design decisions and goal conflicts during the build of our system and the lessons learned from more than a year of production delivery to better understand the availability of data (combining the multiple data allowances with research opportunities).
